questions.text: The concept of emotional intelligence, popularized by Daniel Goleman in the 1990s, has fundamentally changed how organizations approach leadership and team dynamics. Unlike IQ, which remains relatively stable throughout life, emotional intelligence can be developed through conscious effort. Research suggests that leaders with high emotional intelligence create more engaged teams and achieve better business outcomes. However, critics argue that emotional intelligence has been oversimplified and commercialized, with some questioning whether it can be reliably measured.
questions.question: What can be developed according to the text?

questions.text: The circular economy represents a departure from the traditional linear model of 'take, make, dispose.' Instead of treating products as having a finite lifespan ending in landfills, the circular economy emphasizes designing for durability, repairability, and recyclability. Companies embracing this model are finding it not only reduces environmental impact but can also create competitive advantages through resource efficiency and new revenue streams from recycled materials.
questions.question: What does the circular economy emphasize?

questions.text: Neuroscience research has revealed the remarkable plasticity of the adult brain, overturning long-held beliefs that brain development essentially stops after childhood. Studies show that learning new skills, whether languages, musical instruments, or complex cognitive tasks, creates new neural pathways and can even increase gray matter in relevant brain regions. This has profound implications for education and cognitive rehabilitation, suggesting that meaningful learning and recovery are possible at any age.
questions.question: What has research revealed about the adult brain?
